title: [bugfix][improvement] Specific Angular Momentum [xyz] computed relative to a normal vector and some bug fixes

content.raw:
Found a bug,

```
#!python

<ipython-input-7-f5407343f7d6> in <module>()
----> 1 print disk["particle_specific_angular_momentum"]

/home/ben/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.pyc in __getitem__(self, key)
    251                 return self.field_data[f]
    252             else:
--> 253                 self.get_data(f)
    254         # fi.units is the unit expression string. We depend on the registry
    255         # hanging off the dataset to define this unit object.

/home/ben/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.pyc in get_data(self, fields)
    712 
    713         fields_to_generate += gen_fluids + gen_particles
--> 714         self._generate_fields(fields_to_generate)
    715         for field in list(self.field_data.keys()):
    716             if field not in ofields:

/home/ben/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.pyc in _generate_fields(self, fields_to_generate)
    755                         fd = self.ds.arr(fd, '')
    756                         if fi.units != '':
--> 757                             raise YTFieldUnitError(fi, fd.units)
    758                     except YTUnitConversionError:
    759                         raise YTFieldUnitError(fi, fd.units)

YTFieldUnitError: The field function associated with the field '('all', 'particle_specific_angular_momentum')' returned data with units 'dimensionless' but was defined with units 'cm**2/s'.

```
working on trying to solve it
content.html:
Found a bug,

<ipython-input-7-f5407343f7d6> in <module>()
----> 1 print disk["particle_specific_angular_momentum"]

/home/ben/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.pyc in __getitem__(self, key)
    251                 return self.field_data[f]
    252             else:
--> 253                 self.get_data(f)
    254         # fi.units is the unit expression string. We depend on the registry
    255         # hanging off the dataset to define this unit object.

/home/ben/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.pyc in get_data(self, fields)
    712 
    713         fields_to_generate += gen_fluids + gen_particles
--> 714         self._generate_fields(fields_to_generate)
    715         for field in list(self.field_data.keys()):
    716             if field not in ofields:

/home/ben/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.pyc in _generate_fields(self, fields_to_generate)
    755                         fd = self.ds.arr(fd, '')
    756                         if fi.units != '':
--> 757                             raise YTFieldUnitError(fi, fd.units)
    758                     except YTUnitConversionError:
    759                         raise YTFieldUnitError(fi, fd.units)

YTFieldUnitError: The field function associated with the field '('all', 'particle_specific_angular_momentum')' returned data with units 'dimensionless' but was defined with units 'cm**2/s'.

working on trying to solve it

pullrequest.title: [bugfix][improvement] Specific Angular Momentum [xyz] computed relative to a normal vector and some bug fixes

content.raw: Rather than using the YTArray constructor directly, you should use `data.ds.arr`.  This properly attaches the unit registry associated with the dataset to the YTarray constructor.
content.html: Rather than using the YTArray constructor directly, you should use data.ds.arr. This properly attaches the unit registry associated with the dataset to the YTarray constructor.

content.raw: Assuming that YT can handle the multiplication of units, then I think so. I am not 100% sure if it for example maintains that "Msun" * "cm"  = "Msun cm" rather than "g cm" (if that is the question you were asking?)

pullrequest.title: [bugfix][improvement] Specific Angular Momentum [xyz] computed relative to a normal vector and some bug fixes

content.raw:
He's asking if YTArrays multiplied together that have a unit registry (or at least one of them) will get properly propagated to the new array. For example, YTArrays associated with datasets have a unit registry that allows them to use code units like `code_length`, `code_mass`, etc. 

That said, I don't remember how to ensure this.
content.html:
He's asking if YTArrays multiplied together that have a unit registry (or at least one of them) will get properly propagated to the new array. For example, YTArrays associated with datasets have a unit registry that allows them to use code units like code_length, code_mass, etc.

That said, I don't remember how to ensure this.

pullrequest.title: [bugfix][improvement] Specific Angular Momentum [xyz] computed relative to a normal vector and some bug fixes

content.raw:
Because it was wrong (I think) EDIT: it isn't wrong, just a different orientation convention.
L = R x V right? If we were to put this into column vector index representation. The x component of L is 

L_x = (r_y * v_z) - (r_z * v_y)    .... or in the code above... y * zv - z * yv

same with L_y and L_z

L_y = -(r_x * v_z - r_z * vz)

L_z = r_x * v_y - r_y - v_z

Please correct me if I am wrong (I do realise this is a reasonably bold claim on my part)
content.html:
Because it was wrong (I think) EDIT: it isn't wrong, just a different orientation convention. L = R x V right? If we were to put this into column vector index representation. The x component of L is

L_x = (r_y * v_z) - (r_z * v_y) .... or in the code above... y * zv - z * yv

same with L_y and L_z

L_y = -(r_x * v_z - r_z * vz)

L_z = r_x * v_y - r_y - v_z

Please correct me if I am wrong (I do realise this is a reasonably bold claim on my part)

pullrequest.title: [bugfix][improvement] Specific Angular Momentum [xyz] computed relative to a normal vector and some bug fixes

content.raw:
Apologies, I was on my phone and wasn't looking at the context. What you have should be fine, since you don't necessarily have a reference to the dataset when calling this wrapper.

One way to be extra safe, would be to pass the dataset (or `ds.unit_registry`) in optionally as a keyword parameter, and use `ds.arr` or `YTArray(arr, units, registry=ds.unit_registry)` (these two forms are equivalent).  That way when you *do* have a reference to the dataset, and one of the input arrays doesn't have a proper unit registry, you will get the correct unit symbols always.
content.html:
Apologies, I was on my phone and wasn't looking at the context. What you have should be fine, since you don't necessarily have a reference to the dataset when calling this wrapper.

One way to be extra safe, would be to pass the dataset (or ds.unit_registry) in optionally as a keyword parameter, and use ds.arr or YTArray(arr, units, registry=ds.unit_registry) (these two forms are equivalent). That way when you do have a reference to the dataset, and one of the input arrays doesn't have a proper unit registry, you will get the correct unit symbols always.

pullrequest.title: [bugfix][improvement] Specific Angular Momentum [xyz] computed relative to a normal vector and some bug fixes

content.raw:
We need to pick one convention and I'd very much prefer to the one we've been using until now.

If you want to flip the orientation of the angular momentum fields, it should happen to all of them and would be easier to review in a separate PR.
content.html:
We need to pick one convention and I'd very much prefer to the one we've been using until now.

If you want to flip the orientation of the angular momentum fields, it should happen to all of them and would be easier to review in a separate PR.

pullrequest.title: [bugfix][improvement] Specific Angular Momentum [xyz] computed relative to a normal vector and some bug fixes

content.raw:
Mmmm yeah. I can see this one being more of a subject of debate. One which is going off topic with this PR (when really the purpose of this one is to include the specific angular momentum fields).

I intend on arguing in favour of this convention since it is consistent with np.cross (i.e with this PR, your ad["particle_specific_angular_momentum_x"] field is now the same as ad["particle_specific_angular_momentum"][0] which was not the case previously.
content.html:
Mmmm yeah. I can see this one being more of a subject of debate. One which is going off topic with this PR (when really the purpose of this one is to include the specific angular momentum fields).

I intend on arguing in favour of this convention since it is consistent with np.cross (i.e with this PR, your ad["particle_specific_angular_momentum_x"] field is now the same as ad["particle_specific_angular_momentum"][0] which was not the case previously.

pullrequest.title: [bugfix][improvement] Specific Angular Momentum [xyz] computed relative to a normal vector and some bug fixes

description:
Rather than create entirely new fields. This code can compute the specific angular momentum around a central point as before. However If there is a normal vector, the specific_angular_momentum_[xyz] fields are now in directions which are relative to that normal vector. This will go hand in hand with the particle_position_relative_[xyz] fields

Also fixes a few bugs in modify_reference_frame

Attempt 3
